# Timing Is Relative When Trying To Go In-House
## As with a lot of things, there's no 'right' time for going in-house for everyone.
By [Meyling "Mey" Ly Ortiz](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mortiz/)  
onJune 8, 2023 at 11:33 AMJune 8, 2023 at 11:16 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/timing-is-relative-when-trying-to-go-in-house/&text=Timing%20Is%20Relative%20When%20Trying%20To%20Go%20In-House)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/timing-is-relative-when-trying-to-go-in-house/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/timing-is-relative-when-trying-to-go-in-house/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A question I often get asked from law students and young lawyers who are interested in going in-house is, “When is the right time?” or “When should I start looking?” And as much as responses like “It depends” are abhorred, it really is true. It depends on a number of factors. Timing can depend on the size of the company, the company culture, the market, your practice area, and — of course — you and what you want. I suppose a more frustrating but accurate response is that there isn’t necessarily a “right” time, and that timing is relative.

Generally, the prevailing opinion about going in-house directly from law school is that it is rare but not impossible. For example, I know a handful of colleagues who have been in-house their entire careers. At least three of them obtained in-house experience as law students through internships or externships. Two of them are actually my colleagues where I work, two of them happen to be in healthcare, working for hospitals, and one worked for a beverage company. I didn’t even know what going in-house meant as a baby lawyer — but if you know that in-house may be in your future, then interning or externing is definitely recommended.

I have one friend who went in-house at the tail end of five years. She shared that she was given the advice to go in-house around four to six years because you have more knowledge than you realize at that point; and, if you can get in at this juncture in your career, you have a lot of runway to start to develop your in-house career and resume.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
My personal experience is probably the most common — working in law firms, including Biglaw, for eight to 10 years before applying. I had confidence that I had seen enough and had enough experience to guide clients through issue spotting and risk analyses. I also had the maturity and self-reflection to know what I didn’t want in a career. At the same time, although it worked out for me, I don’t like to use my own story as inspiration for others because I didn’t intend to go in-house and only ended up here after rage-applying after a bad day.

I also know a handful of colleagues who were successful law firm partners with at least 20 years of experience who were looking for something different or had done a significant amount of work for a company as outside counsel before making the transition. What I love most about the common experience of those colleagues is that they weren’t escaping or running away from Biglaw but wanted to grow and try something new.

At the end of the day, while there isn’t necessarily a “right” time, most in-house postings prefer candidates with in-house experience, so it is important to get your foot in the door and start developing experience when you can.

# Biglaw Firm 'Outs' All Of Its Flextime Attorneys On Its Website
## This is unnecessary, and it could do a huge disservice to a worthwhile work/life balance initiative.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 17, 2017 at 2:41 PMApril 23, 2017 at 10:12 AM
124
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/biglaw-firm-outs-all-of-its-flextime-attorneys-on-its-website/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20‘Outs’%20All%20Of%20Its%20Flextime%20Attorneys%20On%20Its%20Website)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/biglaw-firm-outs-all-of-its-flextime-attorneys-on-its-website/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/biglaw-firm-outs-all-of-its-flextime-attorneys-on-its-website/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
UPDATE (4/18/17, 8:20 p.m.): Please note the UPDATE at the end; there’s a difference between Littler’s “FlexTime Attorneys” and its lawyers who are on reduced schedules.

Many Biglaw firms tout their work/life balance policies, proclaiming to the world that attorneys who work at their firm will be able to work on flexible schedules on their own terms. But should those firms disclose to others the names of the lawyers who have decided to take advantage of those generous policies?

This is exactly what’s happening at Littler Mendelson. The firm identifies each and every one of its flextime attorneys [on its website](https://www.littler.com/people#qt-casesmart_people-ui-tabs2), all 74 of them (and unsurprisingly, the vast majority of them are women). Though the designation doesn’t apply to Littler’s full-time attorneys, the fact that the firm specifically calls out those who are part of the flex-time program could potentially be stigmatizing. [The Careerist](http://www.americanlawyer.com/top-stories/id=1202783562317/Should-Firms-Out-Lawyers-on-the-WorkLife-Balance-Track?mcode=1202615731542&curindex=7) has more information:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Littler shareholder Scott Forman, who created the flextime program, says it’s “designed for those looking for work/life balance.” He adds that means participants work “significantly fewer overall hours,” and that there’s “no expectation of client development, speaking engagements or article writing.”

The program was born out of the recession of 2008, explains Forman, when firms faced a market shakeout. He adds that the policy also acknowledges the reality that not everyone wants or can be a partner. …

And do clients think less of those lawyers on the flextime arrangement? Not at all, Forman says.

Why is there a need to specifically call out each of the attorneys who participate in this program on the website? After all, as Vivia Chen notes, “the term ‘flextime’ doesn’t have the greatest connotation. More often than not, it suggests a female professional who’s not fully vested in her career.” Lauren Stiller Rikleen, who consults on issues having to do with women’s success in the legal profession, agrees: “[It] signal[s] that there is still some stigma attached that the workplace may be trying to get past.” An anonymous female associate who spoke to Chen thought that the policy of outing attorneys participating in the program on the website was a “horrible idea,” offering this comment: “It basically is saying to the world of clients that I won’t be always available for you.”

That unnamed associate has a great point. By listing all of its flextime attorneys on the website, Littler is essentially giving its clients an excuse to request that these attorneys aren’t staffed on their cases — they’ve already been given notice that the attorneys won’t necessarily be dedicating all of their attention to the matter.

We’re of the opinion that law firms shouldn’t out attorneys who want to partake in these work/life programs. They’re being specifically offered so that associates are able to retain some semblance of a life outside of working hours (not to mention the fact that they’re being offered to remain competitive with other firms). Give your associates a chance to succeed under the auspices of these policies before giving clients a reason to refuse to work with them. Publicly outing your flextime attorneys in this manner could prove to be a huge disservice to your firm’s work/life balance initiatives.

UPDATE (4/18/17, 8:20 p.m.): We received this statement from Littler shareholder Scott Forman, founder of the Littler CaseSmart program, after the publication of this post:

The blog post in American Lawyer completely mischaracterized Littler’s FlexTime Attorney (FTA) program and showed a lack of understanding of the difference between our FTA position and our policies for offering reduced schedules for associates / shareholders. The FTA position is a distinct position within our Littler CaseSmart platform that we recruit for both within and outside of Littler – it is not a “policy” that we apply to lawyers who want reduced schedules.

If associates or shareholders are on reduced schedules, we do not note that on their biographies, nor should we. However, since FTAs are a separate and dedicated position, we do feature them on our website. Our FTAs are an important part of our team and the service we provide to clients, and we believe that not showcasing them on our website would say something about their value within the firm.

It is unfortunate that these pieces advocate for keeping attorneys who choose alternate career paths behind the scenes, rather than focusing on the positives that firms are now offering more options for attorneys beyond a traditional associate / shareholder role. To be sure, alternative career paths, such as Littler’s FTA position, help capture a diverse group of individuals back into the workforce who otherwise might be excluded due to their personal life circumstances.

[Should Firms ‘Out’ Lawyers on the Work/Life Balance Track?](http://www.americanlawyer.com/top-stories/id=1202783562317/Should-Firms-Out-Lawyers-on-the-WorkLife-Balance-Track?mcode=1202615731542&curindex=7) [The Careerist]

# Biglaw Firm's Hybrid Reopening Policy Will Allow Lawyers To Control Their Own Schedules
## The firm also has a voluntary vaccination policy.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 21, 2021 at 3:48 PMJuly 21, 2021 at 2:10 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/faegre-drinker-reopening/&text=Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Hybrid%20Reopening%20Policy%20Will%20Allow%20Lawyers%20To%20Control%20Their%20Own%20Schedules)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/faegre-drinker-reopening/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/faegre-drinker-reopening/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
People are looking forward to having the ability to come back to the office, but there is a real desire to have flexibility built into the new office work model. We have found that lawyers and others at a firm can work at a very high level to support the clients outside of the office in other settings.

[W]e do anticipate that most of our lawyers and consultants will work two or three days per week on average in the office, from the firm office or client location or traveling for client service. This is all evolving. I don’t think any of us could predict what the environment will be even two months from now, so you have to show flexibility.

— [Andrew Kassner](https://www.faegredrinker.com/en/professionals/k/kassner-andrew-c#!#tab-Overview), co-chair of Faegre Drinker, in comments given about [his firm’s hybrid work schedule](https://www.law.com/thelegalintelligencer/2021/07/20/faegre-drinker-to-roll-out-hybrid-work-schedule-after-labor-day-with-flexibility-in-focus/), which is set to commence after the Labor Day holiday. As part of the plan, lawyers will be able to choose their own work schedules, and staff will work all remotely, all in-office, or a combination of the two. Faegre Drinker currently has a voluntary vaccination policy, in that those who are fully vaccinated may request exemption from the firm’s mask mandate, while those who are unvaccinated must wear masks unless alone or taking a socially distanced meal/beverage break. All employees in the office must complete daily health screenings.

# Milbank Raises Associate Salaries And Announces Year-End Bonuses!
## Welcome to the $225,000 compensation scale!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 7, 2023 at 2:52 PMNovember 10, 2023 at 10:59 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/milbank-raises-associate-salaries-and-announces-year-end-bonuses/&text=Milbank%20Raises%20Associate%20Salaries%20And%20Announces%20Year-End%20Bonuses!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/milbank-raises-associate-salaries-and-announces-year-end-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/milbank-raises-associate-salaries-and-announces-year-end-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


 

Bonus season has officially begun! Today, Milbank announced its annual year-end bonus scale. That’s great news for associates who learned that, despite the economic uncertainty at some Biglaw firms, at Milbank things are just fine.

The bonus grid, as noted below, matches the scale of last year’s bonuses for each class. And these bonuses are given to associates without a billable hours requirement, which is wonderful news.



But there is even BETTER news in Milbank’s announcement (available in full below). They’re increasing the base compensation for all associates — to the tune of $10,000 — effective January 1,2024. Looks like Milbank *enjoys* being [compensation leaders!](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/alert-milbank-announces-salary-scale-increases-to-kick-off-the-new-year/)



Well, that is a bold move that runs counter to many of the [dire predictions](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/biglaw-firms-just-dont-want-too-many-first-year-associates/) folks have been making about the industry. It will be VERY interesting to track which Biglaw firms are able to pony up this additional cash and stay on the top of the compensation heap.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon @Kathryn1@mastodon.social.

# Now Live At The Non-Event: The Easiest Way To Grow Your Revenue! 
## Most firms fail to effectively track current and potential clients. Here’s how to avoid being one of them. 
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onJuly 5, 2022 at 2:44 PMMay 9, 2023 at 11:00 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/now-live-at-the-non-event-the-easiest-way-to-grow-your-revenue/&text=Now%20Live%20At%20The%20Non-Event:%20The%20Easiest%20Way%20To%20Grow%20Your%20Revenue! )[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/now-live-at-the-non-event-the-easiest-way-to-grow-your-revenue/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/now-live-at-the-non-event-the-easiest-way-to-grow-your-revenue/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/legal-innovation-center/the-legal-tech-non-event/crm-for-law-firms/)Most lawyers don’t understand how CRM software works. Most pay little attention to managing leads. Most don’t even know what they’re missing.

If you’re reading this, congratulations! You’re ahead of the curve. 

And there’s more good news: The newly updated [“CRM for Law Firms” section](https://abovethelaw.com/legal-innovation-center/the-legal-tech-non-event/crm-for-law-firms/) of the Non-Event is here to help you painlessly take the next step. 

Visit us for podcasts, FAQs, and more. And while you’re here, feel free to download the best buyers guide in the business, published in partnership with our friends at LegalTech Publishing. 

Here’s to your success!

# A Look At The Money Jones Day Partners Really Make
## Given the firm's legendary secrecy, it's nice to have some concrete numbers.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 17, 2017 at 3:58 PMOctober 19, 2017 at 9:09 AM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/a-look-at-the-money-jones-day-partners-really-make/&text=A%20Look%20At%20The%20Money%20Jones%20Day%20Partners%20Really%20Make)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/a-look-at-the-money-jones-day-partners-really-make/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/a-look-at-the-money-jones-day-partners-really-make/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Dana Baiocco

Listen, under the Trump administration, it’s tough out there for a liberal (or moderates with a sense of dignity). So, when there’s an unexpected upside to the reign, you’ve got to take the happiness where you can get it. No, of course it doesn’t in any way “make up” for the myriad of shitty things that are going on, but it’s nice. Like finding a shiny penny in the street in the middle of an otherwise awful day.

So it is with Donald Trump’s pick for the Consumer Product Safety Commission, Jones Day partner, [Dana Baiocco](http://www.jonesday.com/dbaiocco/). The firm is [notoriously tight-lipped](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-jig-is-up-opening-up-jones-days-black-box/) about compensation, calling it a “black box,” so our readers are always [thirsty for more details](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-jig-is-up-opening-up-jones-days-black-box/) on what goes on behind the scenes. As part of the nomination process, Baiocco has submitted a [financial disclosure](https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/4109570/Baiocco-Dana-final278.pdf) and now we know she reported earning $1,224,132 in partnership income. As [noted](http://www.law.com/sites/nationallawjournal/2017/10/16/jones-days-dana-baiocco-trump-pick-for-product-safety-agency-reveals-partner-pay/) by Law.com, her anticipated partnership share and JD capital account have also been valued (though we only get a range for those):

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Baiocco’s financial disclosure, posted by the U.S. Office of Government Ethics, said she expects to receive $250,000 to $500,000 in anticipated partnership share. She valued her Jones Day capital account at between $250,000 to $500,000.

Partner paydays at Jones Day [can vary widely](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/more-peeks-inside-the-black-box-of-jones-day/?rf=1), as the firm only identifies one class of partnership, equity partners, though not all of the partners participate in the firm’s profits. That nifty little bit of doublespeak makes it difficult to track exactly who makes what, though [according to sources](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202779428361/A-Quiet-Law-Firm-With-a-Famous-Client), the average JD partner makes over a million dollars a year, while the partners who are getting part of the profits are clocking in at around $2 million.

Given the firm’s legendary secrecy, it’s nice to have some concrete numbers.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 09.21.18
## * Lawyers for Dr. Christine Blasey Ford say that she's "prepared to testify next week" before the Senate Judiciary Committee on her allegations of sexual assault against Judge Brett Kavanaugh, but not on Monday (an "arbitrary" date), and only under "terms that are fair and which ensure her safety." [[CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/20/politics/christine-blasey-ford-brett-kavanaugh-testimony/index.html?adkey=bn)] * Everyone and their mother and their dog who's been caught up in the Kavanaugh controversy has lawyered up. Patrick Smyth, one of SCOTUS nominee Brett Kavanaugh's former high school classmates who was reportedly at the party where Dr. Christine Blasey Ford was allegedly assaulted, has hired Kobre & Kim to represent him. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/09/19/everyone-in-the-kavanaugh-controversy-is-lawyering-up/)] * "Cohen’s disavowal of Trump has triggered a series of events that turned once very good friends into permanent enemies." Michael Cohen has been chatting with Robert Mueller, and his conversations have focused on Trump's dealings with Russia, possible collusion, and whether he's ever discussed a pardon with Trump. [[ABC News](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/michael-cohen-spoke-mueller-team-hours-asked-russia/story?id=57959664)] * When it comes to Wachtell, "[i]t may be the last true partnership," but that's not how 87-year-old "Poison Pill" creater Martin Lipton sees things. "If I wasn’t here tomorrow, the firm wouldn’t be any different," he says, because he wants to pass everything on to the next generation of lawyers in the future. [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/ma-power-wachtell-could-be-last-true-law-partnership/)] * $26.5 million can buy you lots of fancy things, including a law school. The University of Alabama School of Law will now be known as the Hugh F. Culverhouse Jr. School of Law at the University of Alabama after Culverhouse donated the largest gift in the school's history. Congratulations and ROLL TIDE! [[Sarasota Herald-Tribune](http://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180920/sarasota-developer-hugh-culverhouse-jr-donates-millions-to-university-of-alabama-law-school)] * For the first time in history, there are more women than men at Brigham Young University’s J. Reuben Clark Law School. Fifty-two percent of BYU Law's first-year students are women. According to the dean of admissions, applications increased by 6.7 percent this year, with a nearly 21 percent rise among women. [[Daily Herald](http://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180920/sarasota-developer-hugh-culverhouse-jr-donates-millions-to-university-of-alabama-law-school)] * The trial for Katherine Magbanua and Sigfredo Garcia, who are accused in the 2014 murder of FSU Law professor Dan Markel, was scheduled for October 8, but it's been delayed due to a defense attorney's medical treatment. [[Tallahassee Democrat](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2018/09/18/fsu-law-professor-dan-markels-trial-delayed/1343875002/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 21, 2018 at 8:34 AMSeptember 20, 2018 at 4:24 PM
0

(Photo by Matt McClain/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

# After Jerking Around Associates, McDermott Raises Salaries
## It's all fun and games until someone takes money out of your pocket.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 15, 2016 at 5:50 PMJune 16, 2016 at 8:44 PM
38
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/after-jerking-around-associates-mcdermott-raises-salaries/&text=After%20Jerking%20Around%20Associates,%20McDermott%20Raises%20Salaries)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/after-jerking-around-associates-mcdermott-raises-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/after-jerking-around-associates-mcdermott-raises-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Earlier today, we heard that members of the management committee of McDermott, Will & Emery were gathering, which at this stage in the game led everyone at the firm to expect to hear about money in the very near future.

After all, the firm had already [generously opened its coffers](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/biglaw-firm-increases-cash-for-first-year-bar-stipend-ahead-of-summer-exam/) to benefit young lawyers this summer, so there was no way it intended to stiff them in the world of the new salary normal.

Then this happened:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Everyone expected the salary bump announcement after the management committee meeting ended at 2 PM central. At 2:05 we get an email from the cochairs with subject “Announcement”…. The email is about how the cochairs are stepping down effective 12/31.

Maybe not as big of an F.U. to the associates as [Vedder Price offered the other day](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/law-firm-fakes-out-its-associates-over-pay-raises/), but nonetheless a faux pas. And the cryptic “Announcement” header? People accuse this website of clickbait headlines, but seriously? Firm co-chairs [Peter John Sacripanti](https://www.mwe.com/en/team/s/sacripanti-peter-john) and [Jeffrey E. Stone](https://www.mwe.com/en/team/s/stone-jeffrey-e) had to know what they were doing. Congratulations, everyone in the firm immediately read about your impending departure from the captains’ chairs.

One reason we can forgive and even laugh about the antics of Sacripanti and Stone is that unlike Vedder, they rectified the situation a few hours later. The firm [just announced](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/after-jerking-around-associates-mcdermott-raises-salaries/2/) a complete Cravath match up through the Class of ’09 receiving $300K. Beyond that, the compensation of senior lawyers will be dealt with on a case-by-case basis, but “in no event will their base salary be less than $300,000.” One tipster said the firm has to do this because of compensation similarities with income partners.

Summers aren’t mentioned in the memo, so the jury’s still out on them. UPDATE (6/15/16 6:24 p.m.): Apparently the summers are on retreat right now and were told in person that they would be getting the raise.

# Yet Another Biglaw Firm Delays Its Reopening Without Announcing A New Return Date
## It's looking more and more like the firms reopening in 2021 will be few and far between.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 27, 2021 at 10:44 AMSeptember 27, 2021 at 9:06 AM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/yet-another-biglaw-firm-delays-its-reopening-without-announcing-a-new-return-date/&text=Yet%20Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Delays%20Its%20Reopening%20Without%20Announcing%20A%20New%20Return%20Date)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/yet-another-biglaw-firm-delays-its-reopening-without-announcing-a-new-return-date/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/yet-another-biglaw-firm-delays-its-reopening-without-announcing-a-new-return-date/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One by one, firms both small and large have been forced to revise their return-to-office plans due to COVID-19’s hyper-contagious Delta variant. Many firms that once hoped to host reopenings en masse post-Labor Day found themselves rolling those plans back to an October date. Now, with October nearly here, those plans are being changed once again, and formal 2021 reopening dates are simply not being announced.

Loeb & Loeb, ranked 99th in the most recent Am Law 100, with $385,271,000 gross revenue in 2020, is the latest firm to follow this model. The firm’s original reopening plan was quite accomodating for associates and staff, recognizing that flexibility is key to work/life balance. The firm planned to begin the second phase of its return on October 18 (after already pushing those plans back from just after Labor Day), and now plans for phase two are being scrapped once again.

In a memo sent on Friday by Kenneth Florin, the firm’s chair, informed all employees about Loeb’s decision (emphasis added):

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
As you know, we had hoped to begin Phase 2 of our reintegration plan on Monday, October 18. Unfortunately, given the continued uncertainty created most acutely by the Delta variant, we have decided to postpone our more robust return to the office.

Knowing exactly when we can bring everyone back together safely and comfortably in our new reality remains incredibly difficult. It depends on many factors, including whether we see another surge in cases in the coming months, if schools remain open, or, on the positive side, if we begin to see a sustained decline in rates of infection. These and other developments are incredibly difficult to predict, so, at this time, we are not setting a new return to office date. We do, however, pledge to provide you with at least three weeks’ advance notice of our planned return date once it is determined so that you all have time to make any necessary arrangements for family or personal responsibilities.

“The pandemic has kept us apart for much longer than any of us expected,” Florin continued, “but continuing to support one another despite this distance will fortify our bonds so that, when we do eventually come back together in our hybrid working environment, we will be ready to move forward with a common purpose.”

What has your firm announced as far as a reopening plan is concerned? The more information is out there, the more likely it is that firms will be able to establish a market standard for a return to work.

(Flip the page to read the memos from Loeb & Loeb.)

# Partners Should Make It Easier For Associates To Bill Hours
## Some firms have a penny-wise and pound-foolish approach to billing.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onOctober 25, 2023 at 11:19 AMOctober 25, 2023 at 11:22 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/partners-should-make-it-easier-for-associates-to-bill-hours/&text=Partners%20Should%20Make%20It%20Easier%20For%20Associates%20To%20Bill%20Hours)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/partners-should-make-it-easier-for-associates-to-bill-hours/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/partners-should-make-it-easier-for-associates-to-bill-hours/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Associates at law firms often have numerous other tasks in addition to billing hours to clients. Indeed, associates often need to deal with expense reimbursements, time entry, and other administrative tasks that can make it difficult to bill as many hours as possible. However, some law firms do not provide their associates with any relief that could make them more efficient at billing hours. Law firm managers need to think about inefficiencies their associates might experience and ensure that it is as easy as possible for associates to bill hours.

When I was an associate at various law firms, I was surprised at how partners would not lift a finger even though it would make it much easier for associates to devote additional time to billing hours and earning more revenue for the firm. For instance, I used to travel in various associate attorney roles, and that required me to submit expense reimbursements. Sometimes, I would appear at depositions, court conferences, and the like for multiple clients, and the clients would only be billed their proportionate share of the expenses. One firm I worked at had a program where we could list all of the clients associated with an expense report at the beginning of a submission, and the program would automatically split up the expenses between the clients without any further calculations.

I later worked at a different firm that did not have this functionality. As a result, I needed to divide the amount of every expense by the number of clients and make an entry for each one of the clients. For instance, if I paid $1.50 on a toll, and I represented three clients at a court conference, I had to make three separate expense entries of 50 cents each. This required much more work than I was used to, since I needed to literally grab a calculator (not for the toll example though), write down all of the calculations, and input the many entries.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
I told partners at the firm that I was spending considerable time on expense entries and that another firm at which I worked had a system that made the process much easier. The partners related that they had spent substantial money on the expense reimbursement program and could not change the program or ask the vendor to add functionality. As a result, each month, many of us spent hours that could have been been used completing tasks for clients on calculations and expense entries that might have been easier if the firm used a different program or updated the existing program with better functionality.

Sometimes law firms establish procedural hurdles as well. For instance, at the beginning of my legal career, I worked at a law firm that required all phone calls, photocopies, etc. to be billed to specific clients. Before using the phone, people needed to input a long client number. Associates sometimes lost time looking up the relevant number for what was a quick phone call. In addition, attorneys would have to input a client number on a tiny screen at the copier before they could make duplicates.

At some point, the law firm decided that they would stop charging clients for local calls and print jobs under a certain number of pages. This was welcome news to associates. I am willing to bet that the increased productivity of associates more than made up for the marginal amount of expenses the firm endured by sucking up the cost of smaller copying jobs and local phone calls. This relaxed policy was also good for morale since associates hated completing tedious procedural tasks before they could complete assignments for clients.

In any case, every law firm has inefficiencies in the way they conduct business that can impact how easy it is for associates to bill hours to clients. Law firm managers should think about some impediments to efficiency in their own shops and ensure that associates can spend the most time possible billing hours and producing revenue for a firm.

# The Wall Between Lawyers And Non-
## When you move from a corporation to a law firm, you'll have to train yourself to re-learn a certain basic truth.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onJuly 11, 2016 at 9:46 AM
9
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/the-wall-between-lawyers-and-non/&text=The%20Wall%20Between%20Lawyers%20And%20Non-)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/the-wall-between-lawyers-and-non/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/07/the-wall-between-lawyers-and-non/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s odd:

I started my career — lo, those many years ago — as a law clerk. In 1983-84, in the chambers of The Honorable Dorothy W. Nelson of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, people were people. About a half dozen of us inhabited those chambers — the judge, three clerks, one intern (at a time; there were several across the course of the year), and two secretaries.

And we were all people. When we ran out of sugar for our coffee in the morning, someone ran downstairs to buy more. Sometimes it was the judge (yes, really). Sometimes it was a clerk. Sometimes it was the intern. Sometimes it was a secretary.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Everyone knew the judge was in charge, of course. (Nobody ever called that place the chambers of Mark Herrmann.) But we were all colleagues, working together to pursue a common goal. No one would have considered trying to pull rank on someone in those chambers.

(I know that all chambers were not created equal, and I assume that others have had clerkship experiences that didn’t resemble mine. But that’s how mine worked. In fact, I recently attended the “35 years on the bench” party that Judge Nelson’s current clerks arranged for her, and it’s pretty clear to me that nothing has changed over the course of the decades.

Well, almost nothing: Who were all those young kids running around, claiming that Judge Nelson was their judge, too?)

Anyway, I then went to work at a small firm in northern California. And at that firm, in the 1980s, people were people. The receptionist’s boyfriend batted cleanup for our pitiful softball team. The secretaries were part of the team. Neil Falconer (a pretty important fellow at Steinhart & Falconer) made a point of chatting with the cleaning woman who arrived every night to straighten out the offices: “Noreen is the only person who’s been employed by this firm longer than I have. She’s dedicated to the firm and her job, and we couldn’t get by without her. And she’s a delight.”

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
I naturally spoke to my buddies who worked at big firms, and I eventually worked for one, and I surely roamed the hallways (sometimes for weeks at a time) of many of our Biglaw co-counsel. Those places typically didn’t feel too much like the spots were I had spent my early years. (Frankly, my former Biglaw home may well have been better on this score than many of its peers. I worked in the Midwest, which is often less stodgy than the Northeast.)

As a general principle, however, there’s a chasm at big law firms between partners and associates. And an abyss between associates and staff attorneys. And a gap between staff attorneys and legal assistants. And perhaps even a thin line between legal assistants and secretaries, receptionists, and the many other people who breathe Biglaw air.

If our presidential contenders need advice on building a wall between the United States and Mexico, I suggest they chat with Biglaw partners. Those guys know how to build an Iron Curtain between lawyers and non-lawyers that would put Stalin to shame.

(In my year between college and law school, I worked as a legal assistant at a big accounting firm. The lawyer for whom I worked was an alum of one of the fanciest Wall Street firms. He sat me down on my first day at the office: “At my law firm, the secretaries referred to the lawyers as ‘Mr.’ or Ms.’ [[‘Ms.’ was finally becoming an accepted term by then](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ms.) — even at stodgy firms.] ‘How can I help you, Mr. Smith?’ The lawyers naturally called the secretaries by their first names: ‘Jane, could you take that call?’ But you, Mark, are a paraprofessional. I don’t know whether you should call me ‘Mr. Smith’ or ‘John.’ On reflection, I guess you can call me ‘John.’ Yes, that will be acceptable.”

I knew it was gonna be a long year.]

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Like I said, big law firms draw a line between lawyers and non-. And people pull rank all the time. (Sometimes that’s explicit; sometimes it’s implicit. But it’s constant.)

Now I’ve meandered away from a law firm and into a corporation. And, once again, people are people.

That doesn’t mean there’s no hierarchy at a corporation. Far from it: Everyone knows who reports to whom and who’s running the joint. And people perform their roles, which is a gentle way of pulling rank.

But, when we think about corporate initiatives — we must give everyone open and honest performance reviews; we must strive to improve all of our colleagues’ job satisfaction — we’re not talking only about the professional staff. We’re trying to improve the job satisfaction of everyone — lawyers, legal assistants, administrative assistants, and everyone else.

People who arrive at in-house jobs from big law firms are occasionally surprised to learn this. I recently heard of a lawyer who went to a corporation (not mine) and was dumbstruck by the new environment: “We should invite the administrative assistants to our meeting about improving job satisfaction? Why?”

Because people are people.

When you move from a corporation to a law firm, you’ll have to train yourself to re-learn that basic truth.

Mark Herrmann is Vice President and Deputy General Counsel – Litigation and Employment at [Aon](http://www.aon.com/), the world’s leading provider of risk management services, insurance and reinsurance brokerage, and human capital and management consulting. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Just How Many Biglaw Leaders Are Involved In Extramarital Affairs?
## Hmm...
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 22, 2018 at 2:29 PMMarch 22, 2018 at 1:29 PM
33
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/just-how-many-biglaw-leaders-are-involved-in-extramarital-affairs/&text=Just%20How%20Many%20Biglaw%20Leaders%20Are%20Involved%20In%20Extramarital%20Affairs?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/just-how-many-biglaw-leaders-are-involved-in-extramarital-affairs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/just-how-many-biglaw-leaders-are-involved-in-extramarital-affairs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you’re going to start firing firm leaders for attempting to engage in extramarital affairs, Biglaw won’t be so big anymore.

— [Joshua Galper](https://www.linkedin.com/in/joshua-p-galper-2a98932/), co-founder of crisis management-focused law firm [Davis Goldberg & Galper](http://dggpllc.com/), commenting on the fact that the Latham & Watkins statement as to [Bill Voge’s sudden resignation as chair](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/latham-watkins-chair-resigns-over-sexual-messages/) was [so vague](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/03/21/latham-had-no-choice-but-to-remove-voge-industry-watchers-say/) that it left open the question of what behavior the firm found to be inappropriate in the first place.

# The Law Firms With The Hottest Appellate Practices (2020)
## Which law firms and lawyers were recognized this year?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 4, 2020 at 12:43 PMNovember 4, 2020 at 12:25 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/the-law-firms-with-the-hottest-appellate-practices-2020/&text=The%20Law%20Firms%20With%20The%20Hottest%20Appellate%20Practices%20(2020))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/the-law-firms-with-the-hottest-appellate-practices-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/the-law-firms-with-the-hottest-appellate-practices-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

The legal thread that binds our nation has been stitched into place by appellate lawyers. These attorneys handle challenging, high-stakes problems that can only be resolved in our federal appeals courts or at the Supreme Court, and to thank them for all of their hard work, the National Law Journal puts together an annual “hot list” of the law firms with the best appellate practices.

As usual, the NLJ Appellate Hot List is filled with prominent firms and litigators. This year, these top appellate lawyers were asked about the most valuable lessons they learned at the start of their careers. Here are some of their answers.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[Paul Clement](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/20/appellate-hot-list-2020-kirkland-ellis/), a partner at Kirkland & Ellis:

Be kind. The bar is a small world, and life is long. Today’s adversary is tomorrow’s co-counsel or client, at least if you treat them with respect and courtesy.

[Allyson Ho](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/01/appellate-hot-list-2020-gibson-dunn-crutcher/), a partner and co-chair of the appellate and constitutional law practice group at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher:

If you aim for perfection, you’ll hit excellence. Details matter—whoever said “don’t sweat the small stuff” wasn’t an appellate lawyer.

###Sponsored

From Pilot and Above The Law

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[Shay Dvoretzky](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/01/appellate-hot-list-2020-jones-day/), a partner at Jones Day:

The client’s goal may transcend the legal issue in a particular case. So always understand the client’s objective first.

[Kannon Shanmugam](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/01/appellate-hot-list-2020-paul-weiss-rifkind-wharton-garrison/), a partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison:

As a young lawyer, you’re going to make mistakes. The key is to learn from those mistakes and never to make the same mistake twice.

[Lisa Blatt](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/01/appellate-hot-list-2020-williams-connolly/), a partner at Williams & Connolly and chair of the firm’s Supreme Court and appellate practice:

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Own your own style. Being an effective advocate—as well as someone who enjoys the job long-term—requires sincerity and a thick skin.

[Elbert Lin](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2020/11/01/appellate-hot-list-2020-hunton-andrews-kurth/), a partner and appellate practice co-chair at Hunton Andrews Kurth:

The lesson that’s stuck with me the longest is that first impressions are lasting impressions. Be extra cognizant that first time before a judge or interacting with another lawyer.

# From Law Student To Lawyer To Host Of The 'Today' Show: An Interview With Savannah Guthrie
## Georgetown Law, the highest score on the Arizona bar exam, Biglaw, a prestigious clerkship—all of which she left behind, to pursue a very different dream.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onOctober 19, 2021 at 1:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/from-law-student-to-lawyer-to-host-of-the-today-show-an-interview-with-savannah-guthrie/&text=From%20Law%20Student%20To%20Lawyer%20To%20Host%20Of%20The%20‘Today’%20Show:%20An%20Interview%20With%20Savannah%20Guthrie)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/from-law-student-to-lawyer-to-host-of-the-today-show-an-interview-with-savannah-guthrie/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/from-law-student-to-lawyer-to-host-of-the-today-show-an-interview-with-savannah-guthrie/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Savannah Guthrie (Photo courtesy of NBC News)

Ed. note: This column [originally appeared](https://davidlat.substack.com/p/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-the) on [Original Jurisdiction](https://davidlat.substack.com/), the latest Substack publication from David Lat. You can learn more about Original Jurisdiction on its [About page](https://davidlat.substack.com/about), and you can subscribe through this [signup page](https://davidlat.substack.com/p/all-rise-an-announcement-about-original).

One year ago this month, Today Show co-anchor Savannah Guthrie [took apart](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/14/style/savannah-guthrie-today-show-trump-election-.html) then-president Donald Trump on national television. During a town hall that NBC News sponsored in lieu of a debate, a controversial decision at the time, Guthrie patiently and persistently asked tough questions of Trump. When it was all over, his appearance was [panned](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/10/16/trump-needed-factual-dressing-down-savannah-guthrie-obliged/) and hers was [praised](https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2020/10/15/21518763/savannah-guthrie-trump-town-hall-nbc-miami), with Kate McKinnon of Saturday Night Live referring to Guthrie as a “[surprise badass.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4UFfD0HIhv4)”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
But Guthrie’s bravura performance should have come as no surprise. Although morning shows like Today can be fluffy, with their celebrity interviews and cooking segments—[s’mores cream pie](https://www.today.com/video/make-s-mores-without-the-campfire-using-these-recipes-118278725908), anyone?—Guthrie is a veteran journalist with a hard-news background. Before joining Today in 2011, she racked up more than a decade in local and national news, covering everything from the Martha Stewart trial to Sarah Palin’s vice-presidential campaign to the Obama White House.

Here’s the other reason I wasn’t surprised by Guthrie treating Trump like a hapless witness during cross-examination: she’s a lawyer by training. After graduating from Georgetown Law, magna cum laude and Order of the Coif, she worked at Akin Gump, then scored an offer for a federal judicial clerkship—which she turned down to pursue her news career. Her career in the law, while not long, was impressive.

Earlier this month, not long after Guthrie’s grilling of Trump won the [Emmy Award for Outstanding Live Interview](https://www.today.com/video/savannah-guthrie-s-interview-with-trump-wins-emmy-122266181969), I had the pleasure of interviewing her about this less well-known part of her background. We spoke for almost half an hour via Zoom after a taping of Today (in which she [interviewed William Shatner](https://www.today.com/news/william-shatner-details-historic-trip-space-today-show-rcna3010), 90, about his recent trip to outer space, among other things). Still wearing her make-up, she sipped periodically from a giant bottle of Pellegrino as we discussed her journey from law student to lawyer to host of Today.

As co-anchor of the Today Show, Savannah Guthrie has what is a dream job for many. She meets and interviews some of the most important and interesting people in the world. She’s famous, beamed into the houses of more than three million people every day. She’s paid very nicely for her work, better than most Biglaw partners. How did she get here?

[David Lat](https://davidlat.com/)[](https://davidlat.com/), the founding editor of Above the Law, is a [writer](https://davidlat.com/writing/) and [speaker](https://davidlat.com/speaking/) about law and legal affairs. You can read his latest writing about law and the legal profession by subscribing to [Original Jurisdiction](https://davidlat.substack.com/), his Substack newsletter. David’s book, [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/SupremeAmbitions) (2014), was described by the New York Times as “the most buzzed-about novel of the year” among legal elites. Before entering the media and recruiting worlds, David worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [davidlat@substack.com](mailto:davidlat@substack.com).

# Associate Bonus Watch: Biglaw Firm Helps Associates Celebrate Love By Making It Rain
## We hear that loan repayment is an especially romantic Valentine’s Day gift for lawyers.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 12, 2016 at 11:08 AM
2
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/associate-bonus-watch-biglaw-firm-helps-associates-celebrate-love-by-making-it-rain/&text=Associate%20Bonus%20Watch:%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Helps%20Associates%20Celebrate%20Love%20By%20Making%20It%20Rain)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/associate-bonus-watch-biglaw-firm-helps-associates-celebrate-love-by-making-it-rain/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/associate-bonus-watch-biglaw-firm-helps-associates-celebrate-love-by-making-it-rain/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Valentine’s Day is this weekend, and what better way to celebrate love than to give associates what they love most? Money!

It’s a bit late in the game for Biglaw firms to be announcing bonuses, but it’s standard operating procedure at some firms, especially when announcing bonus information for offices outside of New York.

We’ve heard that New York associates at Morrison & Foerster got their bonus news before the New Year, and that all associates outside of the Big Apple have been anxiously awaiting their bonus cash since then. Today is payday for patient MoFo associates, and now they’ll be able to spend their Cravath matches — plus a little extra on the top if they were high billers (2500+ hours) in 2015 — on gifts for themselves and their loved ones.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Here’s the 2015 Morrison & Foerster bonus scale for all associates outside of New York:

Class of 2015	$15,000 (prorated)
Class of 2014	$15,000
Class of 2013	$25,000
Class of 2012	$50,000
Class of 2011	$65,000
Class of 2010	$80,000
Class of 2009	$90,000
Class of 2008 (including prior years)	$100,000
In the bonus memo, firm chair [Larren Nashelsky](http://www.mofo.com/people/n/nashelsky-larren-m) elaborates as to how much more high billers will receive. The full MoFo 2015 bonus memo is available on the next page.

[T]he Firm will pay an additional amount to those associates who had the busiest years, which we are categorizing as 2,500+ hours. For 1st through 3rd year associates, the high hours bonus will be $5,000, and for 4th year and more senior associates, it will be $10,000.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Associates at the firm seem to be generally happy. Here’s what some of them had to say:

- “I feel like it’s hard for firms to win on the issue of hours based performance bumps. Personally, I support doing something to recognize those people that had to work exceptionally hard without overly encouraging people to strive for crazy hours by giving high incentives to hit those crazy hours.”
- “High billers are upset with the high threshold for a bump (2500+ hours) and the paltry amount even if you hit that. The 2300 or 2400 hour billers are irritated. And anyone who barely met hours is, of course, thrilled.”
Congratulations on your hard-earned bonuses, MoFo associates. You’ve had a while to think about how to spend your cash, but if for some reason you haven’t decided yet, we hear that loan repayment is an especially romantic Valentine’s Day gift for lawyers.

If you have compensation news that we haven’t covered yet, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus%20News) or text us (646-820-8477). We’ll continue to keep you informed this bonus season.

(If you’re interested, flip the page to see the Morrison & Foerster bonus memo in full.)

# Troubled Biglaw Firm Searches For Merger Partner
## This firm needs to take action to prevent worse damage from being done.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 9, 2016 at 12:49 PMNovember 10, 2016 at 10:20 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/troubled-biglaw-firm-searches-for-hero-to-rescue-it-via-merger/&text=Troubled%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Searches%20For%20Merger%20Partner)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/troubled-biglaw-firm-searches-for-hero-to-rescue-it-via-merger/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/troubled-biglaw-firm-searches-for-hero-to-rescue-it-via-merger/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Another law firm needs to be rescued?

For months, King & Wood Mallesons, one of the largest law firms in the world by total lawyer headcount, has been plagued by troubling news. From flat revenue to (ultimately halted) capital calls to partners heading for the exits, the firm knew it needed to take action to prevent worse damage from being done to its European and Middle Eastern business.

In search of a white knight to rescue it from certain doom, it looks like the firm has settled on Morgan Lewis & Bockius as a potential merger partner. As we all know, Morgan Lewis is no stranger to heroics in the face of law firm failure — after all, the firm accepted hundreds of attorneys from the now defunct Bingham McCutchen in a mass lateral hire just a few years ago.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Per U.K. publication [Legal Business](http://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/index.php/lb-blog-view/8143-exclusive-morgan-lewis-holds-talks-with-kwm-as-camerons-circles), the firms had been talking for quite some time:

A Morgan Lewis partner has told Legal Business that talks to combine with KWM had been on and off for months but KWM had been eager to press ahead with conversations in recent weeks. With 520 equity partners, the top 20 US law firm has a profit per equity partner (PEP) of $1.54m and revenues in 2015 of $1.84bn. In contrast KWM has over 550 partners around the world and PEP of $900,000.

It is understood that the talks were led by Morgan Lewis chair Jami Wintz McKeon and involved the possibility of a multi-profit centre union using a Swiss verein structure initially to “test the waters.”

Unfortunately, those talks have stalled since KWM funds partner Michael Halford resigned from the firm about two weeks ago, along with several other senior partners. Although Halford had been central to the discussions, they have not yet been completely called off. The Morgan Lewis partner who spoke to Legal Business seemed confident about the potential combination’s promise, noting that while KWM had surely spoken to other firms, “I think they liked us best.”

Will Morgan Lewis be able to save the day for yet another damsel firm in distress? For the sake of King & Wood Mallesons, we certainly hope so. If you have any information on this potential merger, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=KWM%20Morgan%20Lewis%20Merger) or text us (646-820-8477). Thank you!

# Gunderson Announces Summer Bonuses -- Your Move Am Law 100!
## This is a pleasant surprise!
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 24, 2019 at 3:35 PMMay 28, 2019 at 11:10 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/gunderson-announces-summer-bonuses-your-move-am-law-100/&text=Gunderson%20Announces%20Summer%20Bonuses%20—%20Your%20Move%20Am%20Law%20100!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/gunderson-announces-summer-bonuses-your-move-am-law-100/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/gunderson-announces-summer-bonuses-your-move-am-law-100/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Those of you who remember the great salary hike of the late 90s may remember that the great revolution in associate salaries wasn’t kicked off by Cravath or Simpson, but by Gunderson Dettmer. Gunderson’s quest for top-notch talent led them to take a bold first step that changed the legal landscape for a decade. It looks like they’re ready to make the first move again.

We’ve not heard much about summer bonuses this year. [Perkins Coie technically announced a summer bonus](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/biglaw-summer-bonuses-have-arrived/) but they were already behind last year’s compensation so that was more of a catch up. Couple that with news this week that [almost 70 percent of Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/70-percent-of-biglaw-firms-are-not-on-board-with-190k-for-first-year-associates/) chose to sit out the great Milbank-Cravath-Simpson salary and bonus cycle and it didn’t sound like associates were going to be getting any paydays any time soon.

But about an hour and a half ago, the firm sent around an email informing all U.S. based associates that they’ll be getting something extra for their troubles this summer. The breakdown is…

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Class of 2018 – From $5,000 to $6,500
Class of 2017 – From $7,500 to $10,000
Class of 2016 – From $10,000 to $13,000
Class of 2015 – From $15,000 to $20,000
Class of 2014 – From $20,000 to $26,000
Class of 2013 – From $25,000 to $32,500
Class of 2012 – From $25,000 to $32,500
Class of 2011 & earlier – From $25,000 to $35,000

Associates must be on track for a 1900-hour year to receive the lower bonus amount and 2100+ hours to get the upper bound. If they miss out now, they’ll get them on the back end if they make annual hours.

A great way to start Memorial Day weekend.

(Full memo on the next page….)

# The Top Biglaw Players Who Are Still Holding Out On Raises
## There are a lot of firms that haven't matched the market salary -- but these firms are facing more vocal pushback from their associates than most.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 9, 2018 at 2:44 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/the-top-biglaw-players-who-are-still-holding-out-on-raises/&text=The%20Top%20Biglaw%20Players%20Who%20Are%20Still%20Holding%20Out%20On%20Raises)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/the-top-biglaw-players-who-are-still-holding-out-on-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/the-top-biglaw-players-who-are-still-holding-out-on-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
July 1 has come and gone, and at this point, we have to wonder if [the firms that haven’t raised](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/by-any-metric-these-firms-really-should-have-raised-associate-compensation-by-now/) will ever come around. It’s not necessarily a sin not to raise. As we pointed out in 2016, a lot of firms simply shouldn’t be trying to match the Cravaths of the world, and there’s no shame in staking out a price point below that elite echelon.

That said, these firms really have a hard time convincing their associates that they shouldn’t be getting raises. And the associates are letting us know that they’re getting mighty frustrated.

For example, Boies Schiller, a firm that positions itself as a market leader on compensation, but by all accounts, that image is [fuzzier than it first appears](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/boies-schiller-bonuses-appear-to-underperform-market-but-not-everyone-notices/). The firm employs a complicated formula to determine associate compensation that can earn attorneys huge paydays, but that tipsters say results in midyears often earning less than their peers.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Given the nature of the Boies compensation scheme, perhaps a boost in base pay won’t really change the bottom line for associates, but given the complaints that have piled up over the last couple of bonus cycles, the firm should probably tells its lawyers something about how they intend to make them whole by the end of the year. This is, after all, the top firm [measured by profitability](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/by-any-metric-these-firms-really-should-have-raised-associate-compensation-by-now/?rf=1) that hasn’t moved yet.

No one really expected Greenberg Traurig to run to the front of the raise pack. They’ve already told the world why they [can’t afford to pay their people any more](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/greenberg-traurig-explains-why-its-too-cheap-to-raise-associate-salaries/) despite being the top firm by revenue that still hasn’t joined the market. Greenberg is by no means Cravath, falling way off the rankings when it comes to profits per partner, but it ranks 26th in profitability and could easily issue raises in at least its big market offices. And yet… nothing.

Kasowitz took the associate-friendly step of [moving up their bonus announcement](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/kasowitz-does-right-by-its-associates/) last year, but that love hasn’t carried over to providing an answer — one way or the other — when it comes to associate raises. Last raise cycle, Kasowitz [announced matching raises right before the July 1 deadline](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/in-before-the-wire-another-firm-raises-salaries/). Apparently the modest cost of living increase is turning out to be too much for them.

Locke Lord is at least looking at raises. Sort of.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
The only update from the firm on whether Locke Lord is even considering matching the scale and/or issue summer bonuses (which is highly unlikely) came through the Associate Committee (ironically, made up of associates), who took it upon themselves over the weekend to inform the associates that the firm told them that a sub-committee of the Board of Directors is reviewing proposals to restructure associate compensation in response to associate and partner concerns regarding the current compensation system and are re-looking at proposals “in light of recent announcements by other firms.”

So that sounds encouraging. Still, the firm is falling behind some of the other Texas firms that raised their salaries in time for the July 1 deadline.

Fish & Richardson is barely cracking the top 50 in profits per partner, but associates there certainly are restless, hitting us up multiple times over the last two weeks to complain that they’re beginning to feel like the firm plans to move forward without raises despite trying to play in the same recruiting pool as a number of firms that jumped at the new scale.

This is, obviously, not an exhaustive list of the firms that haven’t raised yet, but it is a list of the most vocal of the jilted associate bases from firms that have hard cases to make for holding out.

Will we see some action from one or more of these firms before the upcoming July 13 payday? We’ll see.
